alternatives.transcript: President Clinton soon will unveil his proposal for Health Care reform and though there's disagreement over what that plan should look like a surprising number of Americans agree on how to pay for it three out of four people surveyed said raise the tax on cigarettes CNN medical correspondent Jeff Levine has our report when it comes to taxing smokers it appears the sky is the limit according to a new poll prepared for a coalition of anti-smoking groups

73% of Americans favor increased taxes on cigarettes to help pay for US Health Care reform that's a higher percentage than those who approve of raising taxes on gasoline or higher state sales taxes and of those who support the cigarette tax 2/3 endorse a two dollar per pack Federal tariff an increase of $2 per pack of cigarettes would generate more than 100 billion dollars in a five-year period the Gallup organization polls suggest support for the new cigarette tax

in some unlikely places even in the largest tobacco growing States 72 percent of those surveyed favorite a major increase and this is in states where you would expect by us to be highest against such a proposal interest in so-called sin taxes on Tobacco and alcohol as increased since President Clinton endorsed the concept the idea is that those who indulge in unhealthy habits should help pick up the tab and not all smokers are opposed I'm the one that smoking it doesn't hurt anyone

it's smoking so if I want to smoke I have to pay the price to smoke it is a lot of money but I think it is a deterrent to smoking which we all need to have but the tobacco Institute says such a tax would unfairly penalize the smoker and have a disastrous effect on the industry and overall about seven hundred and Seventy-Six thousand lost jobs not just in tobacco Banking and other areas that are dependent upon tobacco dollars for a share of their overall Revenue the current federal cigarette tax is 24 cents per pack

back state taxes can drive the price up a quarter or more but tobacco foes point out that still one of the world's lowest tax rates for some smokers price is not an object whatever public sentiment that tobacco Lobby has a lot of clout in Congress and a big new cigarette tax will be a very tough sell on Capitol Hill Jeff Levine CNN medical News Washington

good he's got a new poll shows Americans overwhelmingly support raising taxes on alcohol and cigarettes to pay for Health Care reform programs seventy-five percent of those polled say they would support higher taxes on alcoholic beverages but the focus of the survey conducted for the American Cancer Society the American Lung Association and the American Heart Association was cigarette taxes 73 percent of those asked said they favored higher taxes on cigarettes
and a majority of those said they would support an increase of $2 a pack or more

if I were a member of the Clinton Administration I would be awfully enthused about knowing that I could impose a tax that 73 percent of the American people approved of and were in favor of especially in today's political climate I think that's an extraordinarily rare commodity

joining us now from Washington with the industry's response is Tom Lori of the tobacco Institute mr. Loria if we were to have a two dollar Pat federal tax on cigarettes what impact would you expect that to have on the industry Cassie we would see according to economic projections based on price waterhouse's 92 economic impact of the industry study we would see a job loss of seven hundred and seventy six thousand jobs when one also measures the ripple effect the tobacco industry has and other

Oddities that's an important downturn that the Clinton Administration can ignore the two dollar tax proposal amounts to a 1095 dollar per person tax for those people that buy cigarettes that's it - proportionate burden excuse me let's take these things one at a time why do you think that many jobs would be lost because we're at it would two dollar tax has been calculated to

reduce retail sales by 34% the industry's overall job force of 680,000 would be reduced by approximately 234,000 but in addition we have excuse me go ahead I'm sorry in addition there is a ripple effect that is that mortgages cars real estate and anything you can think of are bought and sold to and from tobacco people as they ingratiate their incomes into the economy that ripple effect

generates a huge job loss and industries that are normally associated with tobacco but have a direct bearing upon having tobacco people for customers now based on what we've seen in the last two business days from tobacco companies there doesn't seem to be too much concern about price affecting the number of cigarettes that people by Philip Morris raised prices today on its low price Brands RJR Nabisco on Friday said it was reversing price Cuts why do you think people would stop buying cigarettes even with the two dollar tax

well I think people some people stop buying cigarettes just because the health concerns linked to cigarette smoking induce them to do so but I think that a nine hundred percent increase in the tax such as we are hearing from the Coalition on smoking or health and some people in the Clinton Administration will definitely have a detrimental effect little establish a black market it will definitely impact on the people that not only make tobacco products of people that would count on us to buy homes and cars US the US federal tax on cigarettes however currently is one of the

lowest in the world Canada has a three dollar and 25 cents a pack tax Denmark for dollars and six cents and US companies are certainly doing very well in overseas markets but these those countries that you mentioned and others aren't bashed into the tobacco industry they have a certain percentage of the population that enjoy the product the United States is the preeminent tobacco producer in the world we don't we don't produce the most tobacco not nearly as much as China Brazil or India but we do have a quality that is

is unsurpassed we have a huge economic sector dependent upon tobacco and we have to take into account that the people that do use the tobacco products aren't really ready in this political climate to have a nine hundred percent increase in the tax on their product that's right we're talking about a tax increase from 24 cents to perhaps two dollars I'm sorry we have to leave it there run out of time I thank you very much for joining us Tom Lauria of the tobacco Institute thank you
